title: DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM
author: Jonathan Morris (005) Page 1
filename: 143 - The Crimes of Thomas Brewster - Jonathan Morris & Eddie Robson_djvu.txt

elements.text: PART ONE
SCENE 1: EXT. TOWER OF LONDON
FX: CONSTERNATION. TOURISTS SHOUTING, SCREAMING, RUNNING IN
PANIC. ‘WHAT THE HELL IS IT?’ ‘HELP!’ ‘GET THE POLICE!’
FX: ABOVE IT ALL, A WHIRRING, BUZZING, ELECTRONIC SOUND — A
GIANT ROBOT MOSQUITO. THREATENING SOUND, NOT DISSIMILAR TO A
SPIN-DRIER. BUZZES INTO DISTANCE, OVER STEREO IMAGE. YELLING
AND CRYING CONTINUE, AND IN THE MIDST OF IT ALL:
[SHOUTING OVER CHAOS] Doctor, what is it?
[SHOUTING] Some sort of giant robot mosquito, by the look of it! [BEAT] Evelyn, watch out!
FX: ANOTHER LASER BOLT WHIZZES. A NEARBY EXPLOSION.
That was close!
It seems to have singled us out for attention... careful, get down!
FX: RUNNING. ANOTHER LASER BOLT. A NEARBY BUILDING COLLAPSES.
We can’t even make a quiet visit to the Tower of London without being zapped at by an alien robot bug!
Do I detect a complaint?
No, just a passing observation. You, er, don’t suppose we’re the reason it’s here, do you?
I do. The question is, why?
What, why is it trying to kill us? Does it really matter?
FX: MOSQUITO WHIZZES INTO DISTANCE. SHOUTS AND SCREAMS.
Of course it matters! (BEAT) We can’t risk innocent lives being lost in the crossfire.
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 4
Then what do you suggest?
We draw it off! Are you with me, or are you staying here?
Someone has to keep you out of trouble, don’t they?
[SHOUTING] Hoi! Yes, you up there, with the wings! Well, what are you waiting for? Come and get me!
FX: MOSQUITO WHIRRS BACK TOWARDS US AND BEGINS TO FIRE LASER
BLASTS. EXPLOSIONS. BYSTANDERS CONTINUE TO SCREAM.
It’s spotted us!
Yes... getting ready to strike! Come on, run!
FX: THEY RUN, PURSUED BY THE MOSQUITO BLASTING AT THEM. CROSS
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 5
SCENE 2: EXT. JETTY/ABOARD POLICE LAUNCH
FX: DOCTOR AND EVELYN MOVE AWAY FROM THE CROWDS DOWN A JETTY
TOWARDS THE RIVER.
[RUNNING] Where exactly are we running to?
[RUNNING] Saint Katherine’s Pier! Nearly there!
FX: THEY RUN DOWN A JETTY AS MOSQUITO APPROACHES.
Oi! You can’t go through here, mate, we’re closed for the night, you’ve missed the last ferry!
You see that giant flying insect back there, the one that’s chasing us?
PAUSE.
Alright, I’m letting you through, but just this once.
Very kind. Evelyn, this way! No time to lose!
FX: THEY REACH THE RIVER’S EDGE. MOSQUITO BLASTING
INDISCRIMINATELY IN B/G.
The Thames! What do you suggest we do now? Swim for it?
Have you ever known me not to have a plan? [BEAT] Quick, onto the police launch!
FX: THE DOCTOR LEAPS INTO ONE OF THE BOATS.
We're stealing a police speedboat?
Borrowing. Here, let me help you onboard — hup you go!
FX: EVELYN CLAMBERS ON BOARD.
[TO HERSELF] One day I’11l be too old for this sort of thing...
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 6
[WHILST DISMANTLING CONTROLS] Yes, that’s what I thought, a couple of centuries back...
FX: DOCTOR BEGINS ATTACKING CONTROLS, TURNING OVER IGNITION.
Won’t you need a key?
Pah! All that’s required is some rudimentary rewiring and —
FX: ENGINE SPUTTERS THEN ROARS INTO LIFE.
Ha-ha! That’s got it! Cast us off, could you?
FX: ROPES BEING CAST OFF.
Yes, Captain!
FX: MOSQUITO APPROACHES, BUZZING. BOAT’S ENGINE ROARS INTO
LIFE.
Hold on tight, Miss Smythe — here we go!
FX: AND OFF THEY WHOOSH!
You know how to drive a speedboat?
Of course! It’s just like riding a bicycle, you never forget! Hello... I wonder what that lever’s for?
FX: THE SPEEDBOAT ROARS AWAY, THE MOSQUITO IN PURSUIT,
BLASTING AT THE JETTY AND INTO THE WATERS OF THE THAMES.
FX: A HELICOPTER THUNDERS PAST — WE CUT INSIDE THE COCKPIT:
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 7
SCENE 3: INT: HELICOPTER INSIDE THE HELICOPTER IS BRADSHAW, ON THE RADIO.

Yes, we’ve just spotted them now. [] Heading west in a high speed patrol boat. [] Swerving all over the place, either the driver’s intoxicated or — Hang about, there’s something going after them, some kind of remote-controlled gizmo. [] Just coming up to London Bridge -
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 8
SCENE 4: EXT. ABOARD POLICE LAUNCH/RIVER THAMES
FX: ROAR OF THE SPEEDBOAT. THE MOSQUITO IS IN PURSUIT,
BLASTING AT THE WATER CAUSING SPLASHES AND EXPLOSIONS.
Of course, I remember the original London Bridge, I went under it in a boat with King James the Second! Woah!
FX: ANOTHER SWERVE AND EXPLOSION.
[NOT INTERESTED] Really? How interesting!
FX: MORE SWERVING, SPLASHES AND EXPLOSIONS DURING THIS:
Yes.. and to the left here, you’ll see the banks where, in Victorian times, you’d find mudlarks, young children, scavenging for jetsam. And on your right, (the) —
This isn’t really the time to play at being a tour guide, Doctor!
Hold on! Duuuck!
FX: MOSQUITO WHIZZES OVERHEAD, BLASTING, AS THE BOAT SWERVES.
I don’t think it’s going to give up.
No. Unless... [HAS IDEA] Yes, it has to be worth a try! Evelyn, take the wheel for a moment, could you?
FX: EVELYN TAKES THE WHEEL. DOCTOR REMOVES COAT.
Why are you taking off your coat? Are you planning on challenging it to a fist-fight?
If I’m right, that thing only has a limited capacity to process visual data, or it would have ‘zapped’ us by now. So, give it too much visual stimulation, and with any luck -
- it’ll have a brain-storm?
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 9
Precisely. It can only cope with so many colours and patterns at once!
But how do you intend to give it too much ‘visual stimulation’ - [REALISES] Your coat!
Can you think of anything better?
No. I knew there had to be a reason for you wearing it!
Other than fashion, you mean? Get ready to slow down, it’s circling for another dive —
FX: THE MOSQUITO’S BUZZING GROWS LOUDER AS IT DIVES.
What if this doesn’t work?
We’ll soon find out! Here it comes!
FX: THE MOSQUITO DIVES TOWARDS US, BLASTING AS IT GOES. THE
DOCTOR FLAPS HIS COAT URGENTLY. DURING THIS, THE BOAT’S ENGINE SPUTTERS AND DIES AND IT COMES TO A HALT.
That’s it, a little closer, my muscid friend, and — olé!
FX: MOSQUITO CRASHES INTO BOAT. CRASH! MOSQUITO CONTINUES TO
BUZZ, BUT NOW IT’S WHIRRING AND CLANKING AND CHITTERING, AS IF BROKEN. IT’S SAYING THE WORD ‘DOCTOR’, BUT UNINTELLIGIBLY.
Is it dead?
Stunned. The visual over-stimulation has rendered it temporarily unconscious.
Not the first time your coat’s had that effect.
I shall pretend I didn’t hear that. [EXAMINING ROBOT] Let’s have a look at you, shall we? See what makes you tick! [REACTS] Oh, beautiful. Absolutely beautiful!
FX: ROBOT MOSQUITO BEING OPENED UP/DISMANTLED.
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 10
Do you recognise it?
No. [EXAMINES IT] Extremely advanced technology, non- terrestrial obviously... a gravity inversion drive...
FX: WHIRR... CLICK! AN INSISTENT, SINISTER BLEEPING SOUND.
Ah. Oh dear.
What does that flashing red light mean?
It means it’s been designed to prevent people like me from poking around. It’s going to self-destruct!
Can you stop it? Deactivate it?
No time. Evelyn, would you say you were a strong swimmer?
[DOESN’T LIKE THE DOCTOR’S IMPLICATION] Oh no. No. No!
Take my hand. And — jump!
FX: THEY LEAP INTO THE THAMES. SPLASH! THEN SWIMMING.
[GASPING FOR AIR] Doctor... it’s freezing!
Come on, we’ve got to put some distance between us and that machine before it explodes!
FX: HELICOPTER ROARING OVERHEAD.
[SWIMMING] I’m doing my best... it looks like someone’s noticed us. The police!
[SWIMMING] Never mind that, just keep swimming, we don’t have very [much time —]
FX: HIS WORDS ARE DROWNED OUT BY A DEAFENING EXPLOSION AS THE
MOSQUITO BLOWS, TAKING THE BOAT WITH IT. CUT TO:
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 11
SCENE 5: INT. HELICOPTER
FX: THE EXPLOSION CAN BE HEARD EVEN INSIDE THE HELICOPTER.
BRADSHAW TALKING INTO THE RADIO.
The patrol boat’s been completely destroyed. [] Not sure, it just blew up! [] They both jumped off at the last minute. []
Yes, we’re getting ready to pick them up.
FX: CROSS TO THE POLICE INCIDENT ROOM:
SCENE 6: INT. POLICE INCIDENT ROOM
FX: BUSY POLICE INCIDENT ROOM AMBIENCE.
Delighted to hear it, Sergeant. What about this remote- controlled device?
(VIA RADIO) Gone, there’s no sign of it, must’ve been caught in the explosion.
Well, keep an eye out for any more, you never know.
(VIA RADIO)
Coming into land... now. Got a visual on the offenders. Sending a photo over to you. One male, mid-forties, one female, fifties.
FX: COMPUTER CHIMES.
Got it. [BEAT, THEN ANNOYED] Well, nice to see it was worth me
coming down here.
(VIA RADIO) What do you mean, sir?
Unfortunately for all of us Sergeant, you’ve found the feller we've been looking for. That’s the Doctor!
FX: FADE/MUSIC TO:
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 12
SCENE 7: INT. POLICE CELL
FX: DOOR OPENS.
Before we start, can I get you anything? Coffee? Tea?
No, I’m fine, thank you. Though I’m not sure about these clothes you’ve given me —
Well we can stick the jumper and jeans back in Lost Property if you like, but if we do you’1ll have to sit here starkers.
Put like that... I’m very grateful.
FX: MENZIES PULLS UP A CHAIR, SITS.
Now, let’s not waste time, Doctor, it’s two o’clock in the morning, I’ve had a long night. What’s going on?
Doctor? I don’t recall telling you my name. In fact, I don’t recall you telling me your name?
You don’t know who I am?
No, I’m sorry, you have me at a disadvantage.
Detective Inspector Patricia Menzies. And as for how I happen to know your name —
Yes?
(THINKING ON HER FEET) Your, um, lady friend told me, she said you were called -
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 13
SCENE 8: INT. POLICE CELL (FLASHBACK)
Smith. Doctor John Smith.
Really? Doctor John Smith? Don’t make me laugh.
I wouldn’t dream of attempting such a feat, my dear.
I know the Doctor. And I know that’s not his real name.
You do?
I’ve had the pleasure of his company before.
He’s never mentioned you.
He never mentioned you either, Miss ‘Evelyn Smythe’. So what happened to Charlotte Pollard?
I’m sorry, who?
Forget it, not important. So, you travel with the Doctor?
Yes.
And what are you doing here?
We were visiting the Tower of London — the Doctor’s idea. This giant mosquito just turned up out of nowhere and started blasting away -
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 14
SCENE 9: INT. POLICE CELL
— with little regard for the safety of passers-by! It was clearly targeting Evelyn and I, so we had no choice but to lure it away.
Which is why you stole a high-speed patrol boat.
Borrowed.
You didn’t exactly leave it in the condition you found it.
Not my fault. The mechanical assassin was booby-trapped. I’m sure you find it all rather difficult to believe -
Not really.
Oh.
I’m a trusting sort, Doctor. Not a cynical bone in my body. Plus, your story tallies with eyewitness reports, including that of our own officer.
Good! (FX: STANDS UP, PUSHES CHAIR) So I can go, then?
No.
Well, why not? (FX: SITS DOWN AGAIN)
Because, Doctor, that’s not what I meant when I asked what you were doing here. You’re really saying you don’t know?
(THINKING) Menzies... are you sure we haven’t met?
(THINKING ON HER FEET) No. I’ve never seen you before in my life.
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 15
SCENE 10: INT. POLICE INCIDENT ROOM
FX: BACKGROUND AMBIENCE. COFFEE MACHINE GURGLES AND CLUNKS.
I thought you said you knew him.

I do. (FX: CABINET DRAWER OPENED, FILES BEING LEAFED THROUGH. ) But either he’s pretending not to know me for some reason, or he’s lost his memory — or... (FX: PICKING OUT FILE.) Yeah, here we are. Bradshaw, look at this photo of the Doctor, from the Ackley House business.
You're right, it’s the same guy, so what?
Is it just me or does he look younger now than he did then?
Er.. maybe. There’s not a lot in it — five years or so. Do you think he’s had a facelift or something?
Yeah, or Botox, that’s probably it.
Probably? What other answer is there?
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 16
SCENE 11: INT. POLICE CELL
You and the Doctor, you both travel in a time machine. Please don’t bother trying to deny it.
I wasn’t intending to.
So although I’ve already met the Doctor, as far as he’s concerned, he hasn’t met me yet. Do you follow?
Not really, no.
I mean, at some point in the Doctor’s future, he’s going to run into me, which for me was a couple of years ago.
When he was travelling with this Pollard girl?
Yeah, but that’s just it, you see. Forget I told you that. Don’t mention any of this to the Doctor.
Because if he knew about his own future... oh, I see.

Charlotte Pollard had the same problem. She met him out of order too, and she told me it could’ve caused a hell of a mess if she’d have let on. (THINKING IT THROUGH) It means, though, that when I met the Doctor for the first time in Manchester, he must’ve been pretending not to know me. Oh, very clever, Doctor!
To avoid letting on that he would meet you again - now?
Exactly. Which means I have to repay the favour.
You mean... pretend not to know him?
And you have to play along. He can’t know.
If you say so. You seem to have this all worked out.
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 17

After the last time I met the Doctor, I thought I should do some research. Well, I read The Time Traveler’s Wife, alright? Well, I got out the DVD - Well, I watched the first ten minutes. But the point is, if the Doctor asks... I’ve never met him before.
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 18
SCENE 12: INT. POLICE CELL
Can you please explain what it is you think I’ve done?
Okay. It’s like this. The Met have been getting reports of some new gang that’s been set up in East London. Led by a fella calling himself ‘the Doctor’.
Interesting.

Nobody’s sure what they’re up to. So far it’s just been odd bits of theft here and there, but his gang seems to be getting bigger and bigger. This ‘Doctor’ seems to be building up to something more ambitious.
Well, I’m sorry — Patricia, wasn’t it? But whoever this ‘Doctor’ is, it’s not me. I’ve only recently arrived in London — and so have you, I gather.
Why do you say that?
Your ID card says you’re with the Greater Manchester Police. So, you have a special interest in this case?
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 19
SCENE 13: INT. CORRIDOR
FX: COFFEE MACHINE SPUTTERING LAST FEW DRIPS.
So did you tell him why you’d been seconded down here?

(FX: COLLECTING COFFEE) Because of my ‘experience’ and ‘history’ of dealing with mysterious figures who call themselves ‘the Doctor’? No, I just told him there’d been some related activity in Manchester. (SIPS COFFEE) Oh my God, this coffee tastes of Bovril.
Yeah, if you want coffee you have to press for tea. (FX: THEY WALK) So you don’t think it’s the same guy running the East End mob?
(WALKING) No. He denies all knowledge, and for what it’s worth, I believe him.
Sounds like you had a wasted journey down the M6.
No, he’s definitely ‘my’ Doctor — and after what happened last night, he’s definitely mixed up in something... even if he doesn’t know what it is yet.
FX: PUSHING DOOR, GOING THROUGH.
(STOPPING) So, what next?
Hold them in custody — if someone’s out to kill them, a night in the cells would seem to be the safest thing.
I’1ll see to it.
Now, if you’1l excuse me, it’s been a hell of night, and I have to go home, eat a microwave curry, and do my best to forget about the insanity that is my life.
FX: AS MENZIES BINS HER PAPER COFFEE CUP, FADE/MUSIC TO:
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 20
SCENE 14: INT. POLICE CELL/CORRIDOR
FX: DOOR CLANGS OPEN.
Alright, up!
(WAKING) What time is it? It must be.. five in the morning?
Yeah, sorry to disturb your beauty sleep, but we’ve just had word, you’re to be moved.
Moved?
FX: THEY MOVE OUT OF CELL.
The call came in a couple of minutes ago. It seems someone in the security services wants a chat with you.
You mean, MI5?
(SARCASTIC) No, the boy scouts, who do you think?
FX: DOOR BANGED OPEN AS THEY MOVE INTO ANOTHER CORRIDOR.
Doctor! Thank goodness!
Evelyn, are you alright?
Fine, apart from a couple of hours spent failing to get to sleep in a police cell — and then, the moment I drop off, being woken up by this oaf.
(DISMISSIVE) I’m afraid I didn’t catch that, miss.
Would you like me to repeat it, louder and more clearly?
Just keep moving, the sooner you’re off my hands, the happier for all of us.
FX: THEY WALK. ANOTHER DOOR UNLOCKED, BANGED OPEN.
WALKING
WALKING
affair.
WALKING
WALKING
identical
WALKING
you say?
WALKING
WALKING
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 21
(JOKING) I like your new outfit, Doctor.
Hmmm, yes - one of more distressing parts of this
Your coat, it was destroyed in the explosion?
Yes. But never fear, Evelyn. I have another dozen coats, back in the TARDIS!
[SARCASTIC] Oh, that is good news. Another dozen,
What, did you think I always wore the same one?
(TO HERSELF) One down, twelve to go...
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 22
SCENE 15. EXT. POLICE STATION YARD/INT. CAR
FX: EXTERIOR DOOR OPENS OUT IN A CAR PARK. EARLY MORNING
BIRDSONG, DISTANT BIN LORRIES, BUSES.
Right then, you two. Your chauffeur awaits.
(WALKING) Our own police car? I’m honoured.
Yeah, yeah. In.
FX: CAR DOORS OPEN.
(CLIMBING IN) Where are we going, again?
(CLIMBING IN) We’re expected at Thames house, I believe.
FX: ONE SEATBELT DONE UP.
(TO DRIVER) Okay, mate, from now on, they’re your problem. Have fun!
FX: CAR DOOR SLAMS. BRADSHAW WALKS OFF.
Now, officer, I wonder if I could ask a favour? I have this vehicle, you see, parked at Monument...
THE DRIVER IS A ROUGH-HEWN COCKNEY CALLED MICK.
Naah. Mister Gallagher doesn’t like to be kept waiting.
Gallagher? Is he something to do with MI5?
(DRY LAUGH) You’re not going to MI5, miss.
FX: GUN CLICKS, SAFETY CATCH OFF.
Now, sit back and shut up. Try anything... and I guarantee that at least one of you’ll get hurt.
FX: SAFETY CATCH ON. CAR ENGINE REVS.
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 23
(SOTTO) Doctor, we’re being kidnapped!
(SOTTO) Yes. Exciting, isn’t it? But if this Mister Gallagher is so keen to meet us, I’m rather keen to meet him! (LOUDER) Drive on, driver! (BEAT) Evelyn, seatbelt!
FX: CAR DRIVES OFF, INTO EARLY MORNING TRAFFIC.
FADE/MUSIC TO:
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 24
SCENE 16: EXT. STREET IN BERMONDSEY/INT. LOCK-UP GARAGE
FX: CAR SCRUNCHES TO A HALT. DRIVER’S DOOR OPENS.
Where are we?
Bermondsey, I think. Of course, I remember when it was all [fields —]
(FX: OPENING REAR DOOR) Alright, enough sightseeing - out!
FX: THEY EMERGE FROM THE CAR.
And would you like me to put my hands up, making no sudden movements?
No, what I’d like is for you to try and escape, giving me a
reason to shoot you.
Charming.
FX: HEAVY GARAGE DOOR SLIDES OPEN, RATTLING. THEY ENTER.
Mister Gallagher? I’ve got ‘em for you.
FX: AN INNER DOOR OPENS, FOOTSTEPS DOWN METAL STAIRS.
(SEES THEM) Who the hell are these two?
This one’s the Doctor. The guy you were after.
I don’t know who this man is, but he isn’t the Doctor!
Actually, I am [known as —]
Shut it! This is the guy the police were holding. I got him, like you said.
You sure about that? Think carefully before you answer.
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 25
Yeah. Yeah, I am sure.
If I may be of assistance, your employee didn’t make a mistake - I am the Doctor.
Really? Well, you’re not the Doctor I’m after. The one I’m after has been running a little outfit that’s been muscling in on my business.
Your ‘business’?

Let me put it this way. Lots of good, honest citizens pay me their hard-earned money to make sure they’re protected from the more... uncivilised element. And it doesn’t look too good if they then find themselves having to hand over their valuables to a guy with a sawn-off shotgun. Am I making myself clear?
Abundantly.
I’m so glad. But if you’re not the Doctor I’m looking for, who are you?
Just a humble civilian. So, if you’d care to release us?
Well, now, that’s the thing, you see. If you were the Doctor I was after, I’d let Mick take you outside and let him indulge his homicidal tendencies.
But, as I’m clearly the innocent victim of a case of mistaken identity —
You give me something of a problem. A problem with one very obvious solution...
A solution that involves Mick taking me outside, and —
Well done, you’ve read my mind.
You could just let us go.
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 26

I could, but then you’d go running back to the police, and that wouldn’t be very good for my piece of mind. I get these terrible attacks of angina, you see, so it’s very important I lead a stress-free life. No, either I let Mick use you for target practice, or...
Or?
Or your lady friend agrees to do me a little favour.
FADE/MUSIC TO:
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 27
SCENE 17: INT. POLICE INCIDENT ROOM
FX: BUSY, PHONES RINGING AND BEING ANSWERED, CLATTER.
What do you mean they’re not here, Bradshaw?
We got a call about five A.M., from Thames House. Transfer request, top priority, under the P.O.T.A.
Let me see. (BEAT) Well, where’s the request form?
Um, it hasn’t actually come through yet, Ma’am -
I don’t believe it. Someone phones up, no codeword, and you just do as they say!
They sent a squad car, I put them in it myself. It all seemed perfectly routine -
Brilliant. A squad car like the one that was stolen from Surrey Quays early this morning?
What?
The officer was lucky to escape with his life. They took his uniform and dumped him by the side of the road.
But how could they know, that we [were holding —?]
They must’ve been listening in on our radios. Oh, this is my perfect morning! Do you have any idea how much paper-work has to be filled in to have somebody formally reprimanded?
No.
Fortunately for you, I do, which is why I’m not going to bother. Our first priority is the location of that stolen car, assuming it’s not already at the bottom of the Thames...
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 28
FX: FADE DURING THE ABOVE/MUSIC TO:
SCENE 18: EXT. THAMES RIVERSIDE
FX: A GROUP OF BLOKES PUSHING A CAR ALONG A QUAYSIDE.
One... two... and push!
FX: A SPLASH AS THE CAR IS PUSHED INTO THE WATER.
Now: Doctor, and your lady friend — into the other car.
FX: THEY HEAD TO ANOTHER NEARBY CAR, BOOTSTEPS ON GRAVEL.
You heard the boss.
(SHOVED) Alright, there’s no need to poke a gun in my ribs -
Where are you taking us?
Nowhere, just yet. (FX: STOPPING BESIDE CAR.) I want you to do a little job for me, Miss —
Smythe.
Miss Smythe. You see, the reason why I know your chum isn’t the man I’m after is because I’ve recently made contact with the real Doctor. Turns out, he’s in the market for firepower.
Firepower?
Heavy-grade stuff, too, machine guns, semi-automatics. He’s planning something major. So I’ve let it be known that I have the, ah, necessary items.
You’re intending to give him what he wants?
First I want to find out what he wants them for. Nobody knows what he’s planning, see. This ‘Doctor’ guy popped up out of nowhere, nobody knows a thing about him.
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 29
Almost as if he just arrived from another planet?
Yeah, if you like. We don’t even know what he looks like. So I thought I’d try to get someone on the inside.
Me?
Yep. I was going to send one of my boys, but you can take the risk on their behalf.
Won't he be slightly suspicious? I hardly resemble a gangster!

So much the better. One of the funny things about the Doctor’s mob is that they don’t fit the usual profile. He’s been sending out primary school teachers to wave shotguns in poker dens, all very odd.
(JUSTIFIABLY OFFENDED) And how do I report back to you?
You wear this.
FX: PLASTIC BAG BEING TORN OPEN.
A hidden microphone?
Wired for sound. So you’d better be careful because, as the saying goes, careless talk costs lives.
You mean if I don’t co-operate, or contact the police —
- I'll be joining that car at the bottom of the Thames.
Nail on the head. Well, what do you say, Miss Smythe?
I think, Mister Gallagher, you’ve made me an offer I can’t
refuse.
FX: CAR DOOR OPENS.
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 30
Very wise. Get in, Miss Smythe. Mick here will fit you with the microphone, it’s the same kind the police use.
So how did you get hold of it?
I think that’s one question you probably don’t want to hear the answer to. Now, if you’ll excuse me a minute, I have to let the Doctor’s people know you’re on your way.
FX: CAR DOOR CLOSES. WINDOW GLIDES DOWN.
(SOTTO, THROUGH WINDOW) Doctor, what have we got ourselves mixed up in?

GALLAGHER: FADE/MUSIC TO:
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 27
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 17: INT. POLICE INCIDENT ROOM
MENZIES: What do you mean they’re not here, Bradshaw?
BRADSHAW: We got a call about five A.M., from Thames House. Transfer request, top priority, under the P.O.T.A.
MENZIES: Let me see. (BEAT) Well, where’s the request form?
BRADSHAW: Um, it hasn’t actually come through yet, Ma’am -
MENZIES: I don’t believe it. Someone phones up, no codeword, and you just do as they say!
BRADSHAW: They sent a squad car, I put them in it myself. It all seemed perfectly routine -
MENZIES: Brilliant. A squad car like the one that was stolen from Surrey Quays early this morning?
BRADSHAW: What?
MENZIES: The officer was lucky to escape with his life. They took his uniform and dumped him by the side of the road.
BRADSHAW: But how could they know, that we [were holding —?]
MENZIES: They must’ve been listening in on our radios. Oh, this is my perfect morning! Do you have any idea how much paper-work has to be filled in to have somebody formally reprimanded?
BRADSHAW: No.
MENZIES: Fortunately for you, I do, which is why I’m not going to bother. Our first priority is the location of that stolen car, assuming it’s not already at the bottom of the Thames...
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 28
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 18: EXT. THAMES RIVERSIDE
MICK: One... two... and push!
GALLAGHER: Now: Doctor, and your lady friend — into the other car.
MICK: You heard the boss.
DOCTOR: (SHOVED) Alright, there’s no need to poke a gun in my ribs -
EVELYN: Where are you taking us?
GALLAGHER: Nowhere, just yet. (FX: STOPPING BESIDE CAR.) I want you to do a little job for me, Miss —
EVELYN: Smythe.
GALLAGER: Miss Smythe. You see, the reason why I know your chum isn’t the man I’m after is because I’ve recently made contact with the real Doctor. Turns out, he’s in the market for firepower.
DOCTOR: Firepower?
GALLAGHER: Heavy-grade stuff, too, machine guns, semi-automatics. He’s planning something major. So I’ve let it be known that I have the, ah, necessary items.
EVELYN: You’re intending to give him what he wants?
GALLAGHER: First I want to find out what he wants them for. Nobody knows what he’s planning, see. This ‘Doctor’ guy popped up out of nowhere, nobody knows a thing about him.
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 29
DOCTOR WHO: Almost as if he just arrived from another planet?
GALLAGHER: Yeah, if you like. We don’t even know what he looks like. So I thought I’d try to get someone on the inside.
EVELYN: Me?
GALLAGHER: Yep. I was going to send one of my boys, but you can take the risk on their behalf.
EVELYN: Won't he be slightly suspicious? I hardly resemble a gangster!
GALLAGHER: So much the better. One of the funny things about the Doctor’s mob is that they don’t fit the usual profile. He’s been sending out primary school teachers to wave shotguns in poker dens, all very odd.
EVELYN: (JUSTIFIABLY OFFENDED) And how do I report back to you?
GALLAGHER: You wear this.
EVELYN: A hidden microphone?
GALLAGHER: Wired for sound. So you’d better be careful because, as the saying goes, careless talk costs lives.
EVELYN: You mean if I don’t co-operate, or contact the police —
DOCTOR: - I'll be joining that car at the bottom of the Thames.
GALLAGHER: Nail on the head. Well, what do you say, Miss Smythe?
EVELYN: I think, Mister Gallagher, you’ve made me an offer I can’t
EVELYN: refuse.
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 30
GALLAGHER: Very wise. Get in, Miss Smythe. Mick here will fit you with the microphone, it’s the same kind the police use.
EVELYN: So how did you get hold of it?
GALLAGHER: I think that’s one question you probably don’t want to hear the answer to. Now, if you’ll excuse me a minute, I have to let the Doctor’s people know you’re on your way.
EVELYN: (SOTTO, THROUGH WINDOW) Doctor, what have we got ourselves mixed up in?
DOCTOR: (SOTTO, THROUGH WINDOW) I don’t know. A robot mosquito tries to kill us, and it turns out there’s another ‘doctor’ on the scene...
EVELYN: (SOTTO, THROUGH WINDOW) You don’t think, this other ‘doctor’ — it might be you?
DOCTOR: (SOTTO, THROUGH WINDOW) Buying up heavy artillery certainly doesn’t sound like my style - and I don’t remember ever being involved in these sort of shenanigans...
EVELYN: (SOTTO, THROUGH WINDOW) So it’s not you? It’s definitely somebody else?
DOCTOR: (SOTTO, THROUGH WINDOW) I didn’t say that. It could be one of my future selves. I wouldn’t put it past them! But if it is me — then what am I up to? Why would I be running an East-End
DOCTOR: gang?
EVELYN: (SOTTO, THROUGH WINDOW) Well, it’s up to me to find out...
MICK: (FX: OPENING DRIVERS’ DOOR, GETTING IN) Enough rabbit, you two. Time to go, Miss.
DOCTOR: Take care, Evelyn.
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 31
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 19: INT. GALLAGHER’S OFFICE
GALLAGHER: Alright, Miss Smythe. Where are you now?
GALLAGHER: RUSTLE AND BUSTLE AS SHE WALKS.
EVELYN: (VIA RADIO)
EVELYN: (WALKING) I’m crossing the waste ground, heading towards the old factory. It’s overgrown with weeds and nettles. Thank goodness I’m wearing trousers, that’s all I can say!
GALLAGHER: Good grief, this is like listening to the Archers. Any sign of the Doctor?
EVELYN: (VIA RADIO) No, it seems to be deserted. The whole place is a ruin, half the floors are missing. It doesn’t look very safe.
GALLAGHER: Your girlfriend’s sharp as a tack, isn’t she?
DOCTOR: (SOTTO) She’s not my girlfriend.
GALLAGHER: Alright then, your mum. Like it matters.
DOCTOR: I’m warning you, if anything happens to her -
GALLAGHER: What? What are you gonna do? The only reason you’re alive is to ensure Miss Smythe’s co-operation. If she dies then you’re surplus to requirements. (BEAT) Where are you now, Miss Smthe?
EVELYN: (VIA RADIO) I’m heading up the stairs, following the directions, out onto the first floor...
GALLAGHER: Any sign of the Doctor?
EVELYN: (VIA RADIO) No... it’s too dark, can barely see where I’m treading. I think I can see rats. But apart from that...
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 32
DOCTOR WHO: ROBOT MOSQUITOS OUTSIDE GALLAGHER’S BUILDING.
DOCTOR: Maybe there’s no-one there?
GALLAGHER: Or they’re watching her, waiting to make their move.
DOCTOR: Yes, or — shhhh. Can you hear that?
GALLAGHER: Hear what?
DOCTOR: Buzzing.
GALLAGHER: Must be the radio.
EVELYN: (VIA RADIO) I think... yes, I can see someone! They’re here, waiting for me.
GALLAGHER: Who is it? Describe them.
EVELYN: (VIA RADIO) It’s hard to see, but it seems to be a young man, about twenty years old I think. Fair hair. He’s wearing — now that’s odd —
DOCTOR: What’s odd?
EVELYN: (VIA RADIO) It’s an Edwardian outfit - like he’s just walked out of the pages of an Evelyn Waugh novel...
DOCTOR: What? But that... that’s impossible.
GALLAGHER: What’s [impossible-? ]
GALLAGHER: BY THE SOUND OF THE ROBOT MOSQUITOS ATTACKING — SEVERAL OF THEM FIRING LASER BOLTS WITH GUNSHOTS RETURNING FIRE.
GALLAGHER: What the hell’s going on?
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 33
MICK: There’s half a dozen of them, attacking the top of the building, firing these laser beam things!
GALLAGHER: Them? What are they, toy helicopters?
MICK: More like — giant insects. [BEAT] Oh, my life! Get down!
DOCTOR: The same creatures as the one that came after me yesterday!
GALLAGHER: What? You know about these things?
DOCTOR: No. But I think I know what it is they’re after!
GALLGHER: What?
DOCTOR: Me!
DOCTOR: FADE/MUSIC TO:
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 34
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 20: INT. DESERTED FACTORY
DOCTOR WHO: DISUSED STOREROOM, FOOTSTEPS ON CONCRETE. DRIPPING WATER.
EVELYN: (WHISPERING INTO MICROPHONE) Hello! Are you there? Mister Gallagher? Doctor? Can you hear me? Hello?
BREWSTER: (FROM THE FAR END OF THE STOREROOM) Okay, lady, that’s far enough.
EVELYN: Oh my goodness, you made me jump. Who are you?
BREWSTER: Me? I’m the Doctor.
BREWSTER: END OF PART ONE
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 35

elements.text: PART TWO
NO REPRISE
SCENE 21: INT. GALLAGHER’S OFFICE
FX: THE MOSQUITOES ARE BLASTING AWAY, WITH THE GANGSTERS
RETURNING FIRE, SHOUTING, AND BEING KILLED.
These things... they’re here because of you?
I’m afraid so. One attempted to kill me last night.
FX: A BLAST CAUSES THE GROUND TO SHAKE, WALLS COLLAPSE.
They’re blasting through the roof. We’re gonna have to evacuate downstairs!
Mick, tell the men to keep firing, no matter what.
Yes, Mister Gallagher.
FX: DOOR CLOSES.
You don’t believe you can stop them with bullets, do you? They’re not going to let anything or anyone stand between them and their objective!
Their objective being you, dead.
Yes.
Well, then we’ll just have to give them what they want, shan’t we?
FX: A GUN SAFETY CATCH CLICKS OFF.
There is another alternative, Mister Gallagher.
And what might that be?
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 36
This! [RUNS AND LEAPS]
FX: SMASHES GLASS AS HE LEAPS THROUGH A WINDOW.
FX: THE MOSQUITO ATTACK CONTINUES. DOOR OPENS.
Mister Gallagher, they’re eating through the ceiling — hey,
where did the Doctor go?
You see that window?
What, the broken one? [BEAT] Oh, right! [CROSSING TO WINDOW] From three floors up, it’s not gonna be pretty... [BEAT] Hey, he’s still moving, looks like he made it!
What?!? [BEAT] Still, they’re going after him now!
Oh, this is gonna be good!
FX: WE HEAR THE MOSQUITOS BUZZING AND FIRING, ZOOMING IN FOR
THE KILL...
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 37
SCENE 22: EXT. STREET IN BERMONDSEY
(PICKING HIMSELF UP) Leaping out of warehouses... no way for a
nine hundred year-old to behave! At least I’ve not broken my legs.
FX: BLASTS FROM THE MOSQUITOS, BUZZING NEARER... NEARER...
You never give up, do you? (MAKING TO RUN) Oh well, discretion being the better part of valour...
FX: A POLICE CAR SCREECHES TO A HALT.
Doctor!
You?!?
Get in!
FX: CAR DOOR OPENS.
Drive! Drive! Drive!
FX: CAR DOOR SLAMS, THEN SCREECHES AWAY. THE HOVERING INSECTS
IN PURSUIT, BLASTING.
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 38
SCENE 23: INT. SQUAD CAR
FX: SIREN ON.
Take the next right, Sergeant, we’ll try and shake them off going through the Rotherhithe tunnel.
FX: CAR SCREECHES AROUND CORNER.
Thank you, Patricia. You arrived just in the nick of time!
I’d hold off on the champagne, Doctor, we’re not out of the woods yet — (TO DRIVER) — now left!
FX: CAR SCREECHES AROUND CORNER. LASER BLASTS, EXPLOSIONS.
But how on Earth did you find me?
I saw the swarm of giant robot insects and applied my keen deductive reasoning.
Good point. [REACTS AS CAR SWERVES AGAIN] Whoa!
FX: CAR SCREECHES AROUND CORNER.
And right again - we’re losing them. You okay, Doctor? That was quite a jump back there!
A little battered and bruised, but you’1l find I have
remarkable powers of recovery.
What about your friend, Miss Smythe?
Oh my word... Evelyn!
MUSIC/FADE TO:
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 39
SCENE 24: INT. DISUSED FACTORY
FX: EVELYN AND BREWSTER WALKING THROUGH ECHOEY EMPTY ROOMS.
You’re the Doctor?
I know, I know - you were expecting someone older.
Well, yes! How old are you, precisely?
Hard to say. For what it’s worth, I’m older than I look.
I see. And you don’t recognise me at all, do you?
Er, no? Why should I?
No reason. Just thought we might have met before, but, no, of course not, that would be silly.
Yeah, right. So you want to join up?
Er, yes.
It’s not so much people I need as weapons.
Ah yes, um... that’s why I’m here. A man named Gallagher has a consignment of machine guns, ex-military, brought over from the Baltic states.
Gallagher, eh? He’d never sell to me.
I thought you could do it through an intermediary. He wouldn’t have to know you were the buyer.
Hmm. Might work. How many - and how much?
Um, well, ‘Doctor’, it rather depends what you want, and what you need the weapons fov...
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 40
[SPOTS SOMETHING] Wait.
What?
On your coat... you’re wearing a wire!
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 41
SCENE 25: INT. SQUAD CAR
FX: THE DOCTOR AND MENZIES ARE LISTENING IN TO EVELYN IN THE
POLICE CAR — WHICH HAS NOW HALTED IN A QUIET BACKSTREET.
EVELYN (VIA RADIO) What? Oh, that. That’s just my, um, hearing aid — no, please - I can explain —
FX: AND ABRUPTLY THE RADIO SIGNAL IS CUT OFF.
Bad luck.
If only I could’ve heard who she was speaking to...
Why? Who was she speaking to?
Who indeed? ‘The Doctor’, apparently. Mister Gallagher sent Evelyn to meet him.
So that’s who you were with back there, Ray Gallagher?
You know him?
Of him. He’s pretty legendary with the Met, they’ve been trying to pin something on him for ages. Involved mostly in smuggling, protection rackets.
Certainly a most unsavoury gentleman...
MUSIC/FADE TO:
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 42
SCENE 26: INT. GALLAGHER’S OFFICE
Tell me the worst, Mick. How many are we down?
Sorry, boss. We've lost Philpot, and Gaz, and Beppe the Greek
FX: SUDDEN CRASH AS ROBOT MOSQUITO SMASHES THROUGH CEILING.
What the [hell] — I thought you said they’d all gone?
Well, I wasn’t exactly counting!
FX: ROBOT BUZZES CLOSER, HOVERING.
Alright — you keep it busy, while I take the fire escape.
Er.. on second thoughts, Mister Gallagher - I resign!
FX: THE MOSQUITO HAS A SINISTER, ELECTRONIC, DRONING VOICE. IT
IS A ‘TERRAVORE’.
Do not attempt escape.
The bug... it can talk!
Yeah, you have a cosy chat with it, I’m getting [out of here] — (FX: A LASER BLAST KILLS MICK.) (SCREAMS AND DIES IN AGONY)
Fair enough, I was planning on firing him myself.
Do not attempt escape.
Whatever you say, my insect friend, whatever you say.
Where is Doctor?
What, the guy who was here just now?
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 43
Detect trace of Doctor.
FX: THE TERRAVORE IS BUZZING ABOUT THE ROOM.
You just missed him. What do you want him for?
Doctor must be eliminated. (BEAT) You are ally of Doctor?
No, no, he’s nothing to me.
Doctor is engaged in acquisition of weapons.
No, no, you’ve got it wrong, that’s the other Doctor —
We are not mistaken. Detect trace of Doctor.
Have it your way. Hang on, you mean the fella who was here just now, that was the Doctor?
Correct.
But, hang on, if he was the Doctor... then who did I send Miss Smythe to go and meet?
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 44
SCENE 27: INT. DISUSED FACTORY
FX: BREWSTER IS INTERROGATING EVELYN. HE KICKS SOMETHING
METAL, A BUCKET.
The truth!
I’m telling you the truth - I don’t work for Mister Gallagher!
Really?
No! He just sent me here, to find out about you.
Then why are running errands for him?
Because he threatened to... (COVERING)... because he threatened to kill a friend of mine. I’m not some sort of gangster, I mean - look at me!
It’s a good story, I’ll give you that. So, he’s going to do your friend in if you don’t come up with the goods?
If he hasn’t done so already.
Look, I might as well come clean. I’m not some sort of gangster either.
No?
No, I mean — look at me! It’s just a means to an end.
But if you’re not a gangster, what are you?
Basically — I’m what’s known as a Time Lord...
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 45
SCENE 28: INT. SQUAD CAR
FX: DRIVING THROUGH TRAFFIC.
So who do you think this ‘Doctor’ guy is?
I don’t know, but based on what Evelyn said... there’s a strong possibility that he might be me!
Okay...
You see, the truth is... I’m a time-traveller.
Yeah. [BEAT; REALISES A BIGGER REACTION NEEDED] Oh my God, really?
Yes. And I might have crossed my own footsteps. I try not to, but when you travel as much as I do, well, you’re bound to bump into yourself now and then.
But the guy Evelyn described, he was nothing like you.
The thing is, sometimes I don’t look like me either.
That has to be the clearest and simplest explanation of anything I’ve ever heard in my life.
I have this ability, to change my appearance.
What, like plastic surgery, making you look younger?
More than that. You’d swear that I was an entirely new man.
Okay, this is obviously insane, but what the hell.. This other Doctor is you, but with a new face?
Going by the description it’s either my previous incarnation - or some future persona.
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 46
I’m glad we’ve got it narrowed down. But if this other ‘Doctor’ is a former you, shouldn’t you remember all this?
I should - unless I’m suffering from temporal amnesia!
Oh right. Inconvenient.
Yes.. I think it’s high time you told me everything you know about this other ‘Doctor’.
FADE/MUSIC TO:
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 47
SCENE 29: INT. GALLAGHER’S OFFICE
FX: TERRAVORE HOVERING.
He’s from another planet?
Correct.
And now he’s here on Earth. Is that why you’ve come here, to kill him? What is it, a revenge thing?
That information is restricted.
Okay, your prerogative mate, just expressing an interest!
You will co-operate in eliminating Doctor.
You’re proposing we join forces? What’s in it for me?
These organic remains are of no utility?
You mean — Mick? No. Why, what — [are you going to do?]
FX: TERRAVORE WHIRRS, PERFORMING FISSION. LIGHTNING CRACKLE.
Oh my sweet Lord.
Carbon molecular content reconstituted.
That’s a diamond. You can turn people into diamonds?
Correct.
This might just be the beginning of a beautiful friendship...
FADE/MUSIC TO:
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 48
SCENE 30: INT. BREWSTER’S BASE
FX: GARAGE DOOR CLATTERS OPEN. B/G GUNS BEING CONSTRUCTED,
CRATES BEING NAILED SHUT, OPENED, CARRIED ABOUT.
Go on in, then.
(WALKING IN TO HALT) This is your hideout? A lock-up garage?
(FOLLOWING HER) It’s just temporary, for storing weapons and ammo.
FX: CLOSES DOOR.
But why? What are they for?
A little job I’m working on.
And all these people, they work for you?
My merry band of volunteers, yeah.
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 49
SCENE 31: INT. SQUAD CAR
FX: DRIVING THROUGH MIDDAY TRAFFIC.
Gallagher told us this Doctor’s mob aren’t your usual gangsters.

Yep. Housewives, students, mostly unemployed or retired, even a community support officer! It makes no sense. None of them has any sort of criminal past, they were all law-abiding citizens, and then pretty much overnight they walked out on their families and jobs and joined up with the Doctor...
You think he’s brainwashing them?
Maybe, but more to the point, why recruit the lady who sorts the stock down at Oxfam for an underworld gang?
Do you have details of all the people who have gone missing? I’d like to take a look, see if there might be a pattern.
You're welcome, we’re heading back to the station now.
Could I ask one more favour? If we’re crossing at London Bridge, my vehicle is parked nearby...
Sergeant, make a detour - the Doctor seems to think we’re
running a taxi service...
FADE/MUSIC TO:
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 50
SCENE 32: INT. BREWSTER’S BASE
FX: BOXES BEING HEAVED INTO A VAN.
Hey, careful what you’re doing with that! You drop that stuff, you’1ll be walking around with no legs!
FX: GANG MEMBERS GRUNT APOLOGIES. MORE STUFF LOADED INTO VAN.
So where are you taking all these weapons?
You’re full of questions, aren’t you, Miss?
I have an inquiring mind, ‘Doctor’. If that is your name.
What are you on about? (SHOUT) Okay, get the doors!
FX: GARAGE DOOR SCRAPED OPEN.
I was only wondering if you intended to use them against the Daleks.
Daleks? Who are the Daleks?
That settles it! You’re not the Doctor.
No no, I remember now — Billy and Terry Dalek, the notorious Dalek brothers. Of course.
I knew it. The Doctor would never countenance the use of guns. Nor would he run a criminal mob. You’re clearly an imposter!
Well, ain’t that interesting? Cos the only way you could know that would be if you knew the real Doctor. (TO GANG) Okay, if we've got everything, into the van!
FX: VAN DOORS BANGED SHUT.
You admit it then?
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 51
Is he around somewhere? Where is he? Where’s the Doctor?
As if I would tell you that. Who are you, really?
An old friend of the Doctor’s. We got back a long way, him and me. You could say we have history.
Really?
FX: GUN SAFETY CATCH OFF.
Enough chatter, Miss. Into the van.
What?
Get into the van! [BEAT] See, you and me, we’re going on a
little journey!
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 52
SCENE 33: EXT. MONUMENT POLICE CAR DRAWS TO A HALT. TRAFFIC IN B/G. DOORS OPEN.
(EXITING CAR) Patterson, keep the motor running.
Oh. You can wait in the car if you like, I won’t be long.
Oh no, leave you alone for five minutes and London would be missing half its tourist attractions.
As you wish. (WALKING) My ship’s just over here.
(SEEING IT) Oh, yeah, the police box! Of course.
I’m sorry?
(ACTING SURPRISED) I mean, a police box, what’s that doing here? I thought they only had those up in Scotland.
Ah, you’ll see, this is no ordinary police box.
FX: HE UNLOCKS THE DOOR.
If you’d care to step inside...?
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 53
SCENE 34: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
(ENTERING TARDIS) Oh. Wow.
If we could take the whole ‘it’s bigger on the inside’ conversation as read, I’m somewhat pressed for time.
FX: DOCTOR PRESSING CONTROLS. DOORS CLOSING.
This is your time machine, then? I like it.
I’m gratified it meets with your approval.
Why aren’t there any chairs?
What?
There’s no chairs, where do you sit?
This is the ship’s bridge, the control room, the nerve centre. Not a place for rest and relaxation!
I’m just saying, on Captain Kirk’s ship they have chairs.
Detective Inspector, may I tell you something, and I can’t stress this too strongly... I am not Captain Kirk.
FX: DOCTOR RETURNS TO FIDDLING WITH CONTROLS.
So what are you doing?
If another of my selves is active in the vicinity, I should be able to detect traces of their TARDIS.
You mean their Police Box?
Precisely.
FADE/MUSIC TO:
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 54
SCENE 35: INT. VAN
FX: DRIVING THROUGH LONDON.
So why are you pretending to be the Doctor?
It’s complicated.
Which Doctor did you meet? Which incarnation?
Which what?
You do know the Doctor can change his appearance?
[COVERING] Course I do, yeah. Everyone knows that.
I suppose that’s why you’re dressed in those ridiculous clothes. Very ‘Brideshead Revisited’!
Yeah, well, it’s what’s expected, isn’t it?
By whom? Who exactly are you trying to impress?
FX: VAN HALTS, NEXT TO A BUSY ROAD. TRAFFIC RUMBLES PAST.
Okay, we’re here. Everybody out!
FX: DOORS OPEN, PEOPLE CLAMBERING OUT OF VAN.
Whoever they are, I’m surprised they haven’t smelled a rat. I mean, where’s your TARDIS?
My what?
Your time machine? Don’t tell me - you’ve bought a garden shed and painted it blue!
You’d be surprised. (SHOUTS) Okay, Trish, Nigel, start unloading.
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 55
FX: VAN BEING UNLOADED.
C’mon. Out.
(CLIMBING OUT OF VAN) Where are we, anyway? This is Marylebone, isn’t it?
What’s it to you?
The entrance to an underground car park. Not very picturesque.
If you’re hoping your ‘Doctor’s gonna come to your rescue, you can forget it.
Really?
FX: SLAMS VAN DOOR IN BREWSTER’S FACE.
(MUFFLED, IN VAN) What’re you playing at, you daft old bat-?
(RUNNING OFF) Stop! Help! There’s a man after me, he tried to mug me, call the police!
FX: VAN DOOR OPENS.
Oh, nice try. (TO COLLEAGUE) Trish. Keep loading the stuff into the ventilation tunnel. You know what to do. It won’t take me long to catch her up!
FX: AND WITH THIS, BREWSTER RUNS OFF.
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 56
SCENE 36: INT. BAKER STREET STATION — ENTRANCE
FX: AS EVELYN RUSHES IN, WE HEAR A BUSKER, BARRIER MACHINES.
Oi, where do you think you’re going?
(BREATHLESS) You have to let me into the station, there’s a man after me -
No Oyster card, no ticket, no entry.
Oh good grief, look, I don’t have an Oyster card.
Then you can buy a ticket from that machine, like everyone else.
Oh, for goodness’ sake! Here, hold onto my handbag while I check my purse.
FADE/MUSIC TO:
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 57
SCENE 37: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
FX: DOCTOR PRESSING BUTTONS.
Well, Doctor? Much as I love standing here like a lemon, it’s not exactly fascinating watching you press buttons.

BREWSTER: My merry band of volunteers, yeah.
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 49
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 31: INT. SQUAD CAR
DOCTOR: Gallagher told us this Doctor’s mob aren’t your usual gangsters.
MENZIES: Yep. Housewives, students, mostly unemployed or retired, even a community support officer! It makes no sense. None of them has any sort of criminal past, they were all law-abiding citizens, and then pretty much overnight they walked out on their families and jobs and joined up with the Doctor...
DOCTOR: You think he’s brainwashing them?
MENZIES: Maybe, but more to the point, why recruit the lady who sorts the stock down at Oxfam for an underworld gang?
DOCTOR: Do you have details of all the people who have gone missing? I’d like to take a look, see if there might be a pattern.
MENZIES: You're welcome, we’re heading back to the station now.
DOCTOR: Could I ask one more favour? If we’re crossing at London Bridge, my vehicle is parked nearby...
MENZIES: Sergeant, make a detour - the Doctor seems to think we’re
MENZIES: running a taxi service...
MENZIES: FADE/MUSIC TO:
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 50
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 32: INT. BREWSTER’S BASE
BREWSTER: Hey, careful what you’re doing with that! You drop that stuff, you’1ll be walking around with no legs!
EVELYN: So where are you taking all these weapons?
BREWSTER: You’re full of questions, aren’t you, Miss?
EVELYN: I have an inquiring mind, ‘Doctor’. If that is your name.
BREWSTER: What are you on about? (SHOUT) Okay, get the doors!
EVELYN: I was only wondering if you intended to use them against the Daleks.
BREWSTER: Daleks? Who are the Daleks?
EVELYN: That settles it! You’re not the Doctor.
BREWSTER: No no, I remember now — Billy and Terry Dalek, the notorious Dalek brothers. Of course.
EVELYN: I knew it. The Doctor would never countenance the use of guns. Nor would he run a criminal mob. You’re clearly an imposter!
BREWSTER: Well, ain’t that interesting? Cos the only way you could know that would be if you knew the real Doctor. (TO GANG) Okay, if we've got everything, into the van!
EVELYN: You admit it then?
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 51
BREWSTER: Is he around somewhere? Where is he? Where’s the Doctor?
EVELYN: As if I would tell you that. Who are you, really?
BREWSTER: An old friend of the Doctor’s. We got back a long way, him and me. You could say we have history.
EVELYN: Really?
BREWSTER: Enough chatter, Miss. Into the van.
EVELYN: What?
BREWSTER: Get into the van! [BEAT] See, you and me, we’re going on a
BREWSTER: little journey!
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 52
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 33: EXT. MONUMENT POLICE CAR DRAWS TO A HALT. TRAFFIC IN B/G. DOORS OPEN.
MENZIES: (EXITING CAR) Patterson, keep the motor running.
DOCTOR: Oh. You can wait in the car if you like, I won’t be long.
MENZIES: Oh no, leave you alone for five minutes and London would be missing half its tourist attractions.
DOCTOR: As you wish. (WALKING) My ship’s just over here.
MENZIES: (SEEING IT) Oh, yeah, the police box! Of course.
DOCTOR: I’m sorry?
MENZIES: (ACTING SURPRISED) I mean, a police box, what’s that doing here? I thought they only had those up in Scotland.
DOCTOR: Ah, you’ll see, this is no ordinary police box.
DOCTOR: If you’d care to step inside...?
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 53
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 34: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
MENZIES: (ENTERING TARDIS) Oh. Wow.
DOCTOR: If we could take the whole ‘it’s bigger on the inside’ conversation as read, I’m somewhat pressed for time.
MENZIES: This is your time machine, then? I like it.
DOCTOR: I’m gratified it meets with your approval.
MENZIES: Why aren’t there any chairs?
DOCTOR: What?
MENZIES: There’s no chairs, where do you sit?
DOCTOR: This is the ship’s bridge, the control room, the nerve centre. Not a place for rest and relaxation!
MENZIES: I’m just saying, on Captain Kirk’s ship they have chairs.
DOCTOR: Detective Inspector, may I tell you something, and I can’t stress this too strongly... I am not Captain Kirk.
MENZIES: So what are you doing?
DOCTOR: If another of my selves is active in the vicinity, I should be able to detect traces of their TARDIS.
MENZIES: You mean their Police Box?
DOCTOR: Precisely.
DOCTOR: FADE/MUSIC TO:
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 54
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 35: INT. VAN
EVELYN: So why are you pretending to be the Doctor?
BREWSTER: It’s complicated.
EVELYN: Which Doctor did you meet? Which incarnation?
BREWSTER: Which what?
EVELYN: You do know the Doctor can change his appearance?
BREWSTER: [COVERING] Course I do, yeah. Everyone knows that.
EVELYN: I suppose that’s why you’re dressed in those ridiculous clothes. Very ‘Brideshead Revisited’!
BREWSTER: Yeah, well, it’s what’s expected, isn’t it?
EVELYN: By whom? Who exactly are you trying to impress?
BREWSTER: Okay, we’re here. Everybody out!
EVELYN: Whoever they are, I’m surprised they haven’t smelled a rat. I mean, where’s your TARDIS?
BREWSTER: My what?
EVELYN: Your time machine? Don’t tell me - you’ve bought a garden shed and painted it blue!
BREWSTER: You’d be surprised. (SHOUTS) Okay, Trish, Nigel, start unloading.
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 55
BREWSTER: C’mon. Out.
EVELYN: (CLIMBING OUT OF VAN) Where are we, anyway? This is Marylebone, isn’t it?
BREWSTER: What’s it to you?
EVELYN: The entrance to an underground car park. Not very picturesque.
BREWSTER: If you’re hoping your ‘Doctor’s gonna come to your rescue, you can forget it.
EVELYN: Really?
BREWSTER: (MUFFLED, IN VAN) What’re you playing at, you daft old bat-?
EVELYN: (RUNNING OFF) Stop! Help! There’s a man after me, he tried to mug me, call the police!
BREWSTER: Oh, nice try. (TO COLLEAGUE) Trish. Keep loading the stuff into the ventilation tunnel. You know what to do. It won’t take me long to catch her up!
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 56
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 36: INT. BAKER STREET STATION — ENTRANCE
GUARD: Oi, where do you think you’re going?
EVELYN: (BREATHLESS) You have to let me into the station, there’s a man after me -
GUARD: No Oyster card, no ticket, no entry.
EVELYN: Oh good grief, look, I don’t have an Oyster card.
GUARD: Then you can buy a ticket from that machine, like everyone else.
EVELYN: Oh, for goodness’ sake! Here, hold onto my handbag while I check my purse.
EVELYN: FADE/MUSIC TO:
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 57
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 37: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
MENZIES: Well, Doctor? Much as I love standing here like a lemon, it’s not exactly fascinating watching you press buttons.
DOCTOR: No sign of any other TARDISes in the London area. But.. hello - that’s odd!
MENZIES: What’s odd?
DOCTOR: It’s not a TARDIS... but someone does seem to have activated a time machine!
MENZIES: Oh, a time machine. I thought it might have been something bad.
DOCTOR: Oh, it is bad, Patricia. I’d even go so far as to say that it
DOCTOR: merits the use of the word ‘extremely’!
DOCTOR: FADE/MUSIC TO:
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 58
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 38: INT. BAKER STREET STATION — PLATFORM/TUBE CARRIAGE
EVELYN: Hold the doors! Hold the doors!
EVELYN: BEEPING NOISE.
JARED: You alright, miss?
EVELYN: Thank you, young man — and no, I’m not alright, there’s someone chasing me...
JARED: It’s okay, love, we’re moving. [BEAT] Here, you can take my seat if you want.
FLIP: Jared, what’s going on?
JARED: This old dear thinks some bloke’s after her.
FLIP: No way! Are you okay?
EVELYN: I’ll be fine, once I get my breath back. Thank you. And I’11 have you know that I’m not an ‘old dear’ quite yet!
EVELYN: TRAIN P/A ANNOUNCEMENT: The next station is Great Portland Street. The next station is Great Portland Street.
EVELYN: GROWS LOUDER, SHAKING AND RATTLING OMINOUSLY.
JARED: Hey, Flip, check out the guy in the next carriage.
FLIP: What guy?
JARED: The one in fancy dress...
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 59
EVELYN: Oh no. He must’ve followed me.
JARED: That’s the guy who was chasing you? Caractacus Potts?
EVELYN: He mustn’t see me.
FLIP: He’s heading down the carriage, I’d get off at the next stop if I was you.
JARED: Now you mention it, shouldn’t we be slowing down for the next stop? I’d swear we were getting faster!
JARED: ROAR. PASSENGERS BEGIN TO SCREAM IN TERROR.
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 60
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 39: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
MENZIES: I’m guessing that noise isn’t good news either.
DOCTOR: It means someone’s just smashed a hole in the fabric of the universe. A temporal breach!
MENZIES: And one of those is?
DOCTOR: A wormhole, Detective Menzies, a space-time wormhole!
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 61
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 40: INT. TUBE CARRIAGE
DOCTOR WHO: MUTTERING, CHATTERING AND SCREAMING IN ALARM.
FLIP: Jared, what’s happening?
JARED: Don’t ask me! The rate this thing’s going, I’m surprised it hasn’t fallen to pieces!
JARED: CRASH OF LIGHTING.
EVELYN: We’re slowing down, thank goodness.
FLIP: But that’s... daylight! It’s daylight outside! Where are we?
JARED: Looks like... a tropical jungle. (WHISTLE IN AWE)
FLIP: But this is meant to be Great Portland Street tube! Not the middle of the Amazonian Rainforest!
FLIP: BUT NO ORDINARY JUNGLE — IT GURGLES AND BELCHES LIKE MUD, WITH STRANGE ALIEN GROANS AND SHRIEKS.
EVELYN: I think we’ve gone further than that... look at the sky!
JARED: What? Two moons.. two moons! And stars, loads of stars!
FLIP: I don’t get it, Jared, what is it?
EVELYN: Isn’t it obvious? We’re on an alien planet.
EVELYN: JUNGLE, WITH STRANGE WHOOPS, CHITTERS, RUSTLING LEAVES.
BREWSTER: (ENTERING CARRIAGE) Miss Smythe. Glad I caught up with you.
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 62
EVELYN: Where are we?
BREWSTER: End of the line. Welcome - to the planet Symbios! (PRONOUNCED ‘SIM-BEE-OSS’.)
BREWSTER: FADE/MUSIC TO:
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 63
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 41: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
DOCTOR: Got it! The temporal breach appears to be located in Great Portland Street!
MENZIES: You’re joking, right?
DOCTOR: Right next to the Underground Station! Unfortunately, trying to investigate in the TARDIS would be like flying into a hurricane.
MENZIES: Is this your way of asking for another lift?
DOCTOR: It would save me having to take the bus.
MENZIES: Okay, open the doors. Let’s go.
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 64
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 42: EXT. MONUMENT
DOCTOR: I do apologise, Detective-Inspector, if I appear to be using you as some kind of taxi service.
MENZIES: Yeah, just call me a [cab] —
GALLAGHER: (CLEARING THROAT) Doctor!
DOCTOR: Oh no.
GALLAGHER: What’s this? Assisting the police with their enquiries?
MENZIES: Mister Gallagher. What are you doing here?
GALLAGHER: I’d been hoping to run into your again, my associates had a great deal of trouble tracking you down.
DOCTOR: What associates?
DOCTOR: BEFORE BEING JOINED BY SEVERAL MORE.
GALLAGHER: You know the saying, ‘my enemy’s enemy’? Turns out I’m not alone in wanting you deceased.
MENZIES: (SOTTO) Doctor, we’ll have to leg it to the car —
DOCTOR: Patricia, you wouldn’t stand a chance!
GALLAGHER: No, go ahead. Give it your best shot!
GALLAGHER: PASSERS-BY.
MENZIES: What the... Sergeant Patterson, he was in there!
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 65
GALLAGHER: (SARCASTIC) Oh no, the death of a police officer on my conscience.
TERRAVORE: (BUZZING CLOSER) This is Doctor. Doctor must be eliminated.
GALLAGHER: Be my guest.
DOCTOR: (SOTTO) Patricia, back into the TARDIS. Now!
MENZIES: (SOTTO) What about you?
DOCTOR: (SOTTO) I’11 be right behind you! (TO TERRAVORE) Eliminated, you say? Hadn’t you better come a little closer? Just to make sure? (FX: TERRAVORE BUZZES CLOSER STILL) That’s it. Closer. Closer. Aaand — (GRABBING TERRAVORE’S WINGS) — gotcha!
TERRAVORE: Doctor must — release — wingzzz!
DOCTOR: (STRUGGLING WITH TERRAVORE) Ohhh no. Goodbye, Mr Gallagher-!
GALLAGHER: What d’you think you’re playing at-? Doctor-?
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 66
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 43: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
DOCTOR WHO: TERRAVORE.
TERRAVORE: Release — wingzzz!
DOCTOR: Quiet, you-!
MENZIES: Doctor? What’ve you brought that thing in for-?
DOCTOR: Just close the doors, Patricia, I can’t hold this thing much longer —
MENZIES: Yeah, what now-?
DOCTOR: Now — I need you to press the yellow button third from left on the next panel!
MENZIES: Yellow button, third from left —
DOCTOR: Hurry, Patricia!
MENZIES: Can’t find a yellow button. There’s one that’s sort of ochre —
DOCTOR: That’s the one!
DOCTOR: SOOTHING, THROBBING, LIKE A FORCEFIELD. TERRAVORE CALMS.
MENZIES: It’s not moving. What have you done?
DOCTOR: Caught it in a sensory disorientation force-field.
MENZIES: A what?
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 67
DOCTOR: A fly, trapped in amber! (FX: PRESSING BUTTONS) Now, time we were out of here...
DOCTOR: FADE/MUSIC TO:
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 68
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 44: EXT. JUNGLE ON THE PLANET SYMBIOS
BREWSTER: Okay, out of the train. Come on, we haven’t got all day!
JARED: (STEPPING OUT) What’s going on?
FLIP: Where are we?
BREWSTER: Just shut up and do as I say!
JARED: Oh right, you’re the big man here, are you?
BREWSTER: Hey, I just shifted an underground train half-way across the galaxy, if that doesn’t deserve some respect I don’t know what does!
EVELYN: This is your doing, then?
BREWSTER: Enough questions. Everybody out of the carriage? Good. Now, you see them crates over there? — Pick them up.
JARED: Why? What’s in them?
BREWSTER: Machine guns.
FLIP: Machine guns?
BREWSTER: Yeah, but don’t get any clever ideas, they’re not loaded. [BEAT] Look, will you lot just get on with it?
FLIP: Hey, Jared, look at the people in the other carriage — they’re
FLIP: not moving!
JARED: Yeah, like they’re frozen.
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 69
EVELYN: Or ina trance.
BREWSTER: It’s only temporary. I’d take a step back, if I were you!
BREWSTER: RUSHING, BREAKING-THE-SOUND-BARRIER SOUND. THE SOUND OF THE TRAIN VANISHING. THE PASSENGERS WHO HAVE GOT OFF THE TRAIN MUTTER IN AWE.
JARED: It’s gone. Vanished!
FLIP: Into, like, nothing!
BREWSTER: Yeah, it’s important the interface isn’t left open.
EVELYN: So I take it we can’t get back?
BREWSTER: That’s right. And as I’m the only one who knows their way around here, you’d better start doing as you’re told! (ALOUD) Crates! This way! Move!

DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 70
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 45: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
DOCTOR: Listen to me, my bug-eyed friend. If I were the sort of person to stoop to threats, I’d remind you I can increase the intensity of this force-field. So, for the last time, what are you?
TERRAVORE: I am Terravore.
DOCTOR: Terravore?
MENZIES: You know these things?
DOCTOR: No. I’ve never met them before, in all my travels.
TERRAVORE: You are Doctor. Doctor must be eliminated.
MENZIES: They seem to know you. Are you sure you haven’t forgotten?
DOCTOR: If I had, I’d hardly know about it, would I? (BEAT) Tell me, how do you know who I am?
TERRAVORE: Doctor constitutes threat to Terravore objectives.
DOCTOR: Do you mean I’ve defeated you? Thwarted your plans?
TERRAVORE: Correct.
DOCTOR: Well, no wonder you don’t like me!
MENZIES: I thought you said you’d never — (CATCHING ON) Oh, but this could all be in your future, couldn’t it?
DOCTOR: You catch on fast. But the problem is, I mustn’t know too much about my own fate -
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 71
MENZIES: - because it could create some sort of paradox.
DOCTOR: Well, yes, but mainly because it would spoil all the fun of finding out!
DOCTOR: FADE/MUSIC TO:
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 72
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 46: EXT. JUNGLE ON THE PLANET SYMBIOS
DOCTOR WHO: NOISES, APPROACHING A RUSHING RIVER/WATERFALL.
BREWSTER: Keep moving!
JARED: What’s the big rush?
BREWSTER: Because if you don’t, you'll die.
JARED: Are you threatening us?
BREWSTER: Not me. We’re not the only ones on this planet, it’s not safe out in the open. Now hurry up!
FLIP: You alright, Miss?
EVELYN: Oh, yes. I’ve just had rather a long day, that’s all. And it’s very hot and clammy...
FLIP: You know this guy, this ‘Doctor’?
EVELYN: That’s not his name. I don’t know who he is. I’m sorry, I haven’t introduced myself. I’m Evelyn.
FLIP: Flip. Short for Philippa. This is my boyfriend, Jared.
JARED: Hi.
FLIP: We were just heading out to a friend’s party. Didn’t expect to end up.. wherever the hell we are.
EVELYN: It’s very strange, isn’t it? It seems to be a jungle - but where are all the birds, the insects, the animals?
JARED: Yeah, well, I’m not exactly desperate to meet the wildlife.
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 73
EVELYN: And the trees — if that’s what they are — don’t they remind you of something?
FLIP: Now you say, they do look a bit... I don’t know, like bones, or Spare ribs. Kind of fleshy... and wet!
JARED: And all these roots... they’re more like twisted cables!
EVELYN: Or veins! The ground too... I’m not entirely sure this is earth we’re treading on - it appears to be pulsating. And that smell. It’s...
FLIP: Like someone’s been sick?
EVELYN: I wasn’t going to say it, but yes. Bile! This whole place, it’s like wandering through an anatomy class.
JARED: So that’s, what, bubbling mud? Or lava, like in Iceland?
FLIP: It’s blood, isn’t it? Rivers of blood!
EVELYN: Yes.. I don’t think this is an ordinary alien planet.
JARED: Oh, visit a lot of alien planets, do you?
EVELYN: I do, as it happens. But this place... it’s more like one vast living organism!
EVELYN: FADE/MUSIC TO:
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 74

DOCTOR: But why? Why come to Earth to kill me now?
TERRAVORE: Doctor constitutes threat to Terravore objectives.
DOCTOR: You mean, your current objectives?
TERRAVORE: Correct.
DOCTOR: Which are?
TERRAVORE: Assimilation of planet. Extraction and exploitation of all chemical resources.
MENZIES: Yeah, well, think you’1ll find we’ve extracted and exploited most of those ourselves.
TERRAVORE: We do not assimilate planet Earth. We assimilate planet Symbios. (PRONOUNCED ‘SIM-BEE-OSS’.)
TERRAVORE: FADE/MUSIC TO:
DOCTOR WHO: THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 75
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 48: EXT. JUNGLE ON THE PLANET SYMBIOS
BREWSTER: Come on, nearly there!
JARED: Uurgh, what is this stuff we’re walking in?
FLIP: I don’t care, I just want to know whether I’1l ever be able to get it off my shoes.
JARED: Listen, Doctor whatever-you’re-called, it’s time you gave us some answers. Why’ve you brought us here?
FLIP: Yeah. And what are all these guns for? My arms are knackered, lugging these crates!
BREWSTER: If you must ask, the reason you're here, and reason we need
BREWSTER: all these weapons, is because I’m trying to save this planet!
EVELYN: Save it? Save it from what?
BREWSTER: Oh no. I didn’t think they’d made it this far...
JARED: What are they?
BREWSTER: Terravore.

JARED: Why are they trying to kill us? We haven’t done nothing!

EVELYN: I suspect it’s guilt by association, isn’t that right?
BREWSTER: Just stay together, all of you — stay with me!
JARED: You’ve got to be joking. Run! Everyone! Run!!!

BREWSTER: (QUIETLY, TO HIMSELF) At last!
JARED: C’mon, Flip! What’s stopping you?!? We’ve got to run!

SCENE 50: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
FX: IN FLIGHT. FORCEFIELD AND TERRAVORE.
So this Doctor — who’s you at some point in your past or
future, you’re not sure which — this other Doctor is running an East End mob, in order to help save an alien world?
That would appear be the case, Detective-Inspector.
Good, because for a minute back there, I thought I was in danger of becoming confused.
FX: TERRAVORE BEGINS MAKING A STRAINED WHIRRING SOUND.
Connection broken. Connection broken. (REPEATS IN B/G)
What’s up with Metal Mickey?
FX: DOCTOR PRESSES BUTTONS ON THE CONSOLE.
It’s attempting to make radio contact! A call for help? Or to request further instructions? Either way, it can’t communicate
while the TARDIS remains in the vortex.
You mean it can’t get a mobile signal?
Which is interesting. It means I should be able to — yes!
FX: DOCTOR PRESSING BUTTONS, DASHING ABOUT THE CONSOLE.
Able to yes what?
Triangulate the source of the control transmission!
FX: TERRAVORE STARTS GROANING, SHRIEKING, LOSING POWER.
Connection broken! Restore contact! Connection broken —
I think it’s having some sort of breakdown.
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 79
Not quite. It appears to be reliant upon that link in some way. Without it, it has no independent initiative.
Fx: TERRAVORE DIES, FALLS SILENT DURING THIS.
I know some people who are like that with their i-phones.
Maybe it is something more - a hive mind? A gestalt?
Well, this one seems to be out for the count.
Fx: MENZIES TAPS IT ON THE HEAD. IT’S METAL.
Not dead. Inactive. Awaiting instructions!
Oh. So where’s it getting these instructions from?
FX: MORE BUTTONS BEING PRESSED.
The Earth. South London. According to the instruments, it
appears to be - just outside Penge?!?
FADE/MUSIC TO:
THE GATHERING SWARM by Jonathan Morris (005) Page 80
SCENE 51: INT. UNDERGROUND TUNNEL ON SYMBIOS
FX: WATER DRIPPING, ECHOEY ACOUSTICS. PEOPLE GETTING THEIR
BREATH, WHIMPERING. THIS INCLUDES EVELYN, FLIP AND JARED.
What happened? Where are we?
Where do you think? You were pulled through the ground.
Yeah, I got that part, but why?
I think I know why. This world... it came to our rescue!
Alright, everyone, this way with the crates. We’re nearly home and dry.
FX: THEY START TRUDGING THROUGH THE SQUELCHY TUNNELS.
Not that dry. The walls, they’re all... squidgy.
I think, my dear, we’re in some sort of artery.
Or duct. Or even worse, we’re in —
